Prompt: My husband works a lot which really helps our family. The problem is he never wants to go anywhere with my children and me. Most every time I talk with him, he has something negative to say about me. Something I didn’t do right. This is really starting to wear on me. My Self Esteem is pretty bad and this makes it worse. I also get very anxious when I know he’s coming home soon, because I know it is going to be constant critiques. Also, when I ask him if he wants to go someplace with me and the kids, he never wants to and gets upset about it. I get in a bad mood too and he ends up leaving. In which doesn’t make any sense because he said he didn’t want to go anywhere. I have told him how much these things bother me. Every time, he turns around and says what bother him. Nothing gets resolved. I work from home and it’s difficult because I am also watching the kids. He doesn’t like anyone else watching the kids so I try to the majority of the time, unless I have somewhere important to go to. We used to be a lot different. We would go out to dinner, shopping, ext. We would watch TV together and he really didn’t critique me all too much. He used to say good things about me in which he doesn’t say anymore. For example, he used to call me “pretty girl”. He has not said that for awhile now. We have also went through some crap that hurt our relationship. I wasn’t very mature when we started dating so I made some poor decisions that I would never do presently. I’d love to know what changed our relationship so much? I cannot say I’m overall miserable because I do enjoy spending time with my children. My underneath layer is hurt, badly. I feel like my feelings don’t matter. I don’t know when and if to call it quits. We have been married for 6 years and I don’t give up easily. I do love him but I wish he was how he was when we got married. He actually cared and SHOWED me how much he loved me.

His first response was “You don’t like me.” I am also sick with Lupus and when this first big argument came I was caring for several children. This cycle has been going on for about 5 years now. My husband and I explained why we needed him to call and he nodded his head as though he understood. His response is usually the same. “I may come, not sure what I am doing yet.” That ends up tying up our night as we don’t know if he is coming or not. If we invite others to play cards we may not be able to if he just shows up. Hubby feels guilty telling him that we are not up for company. It is badly straining our marriage as I can’t even rely on having a peaceful night. Hubby is stressed because he doesn’t want him doing it either but would put up with it if I didn’t complain. She believes her face is ugly, and just recently started feeling a lot of negatively about her body. Prompt: I have PTSD, have been in a few abusive relationships, have over come them all and have always been fine. This last one, about 5 months ago, he got me pregnant, he was abusive but one day he went to the extreme and almost killed me after I found out we were pregnant… this was all in front of my first son. I believe it’s because it was in front of my son that it’s affecting me so bad, but I have never been this clueless as to what to do to overcome this. I am now 6 months pregnant, lately (past 3 or more weeks) every time I lay down to sleep or am calm, the memory and flashbacks hit me hard, and all I think about is how my son saw it Even after my 10 hour graveyard shift sometime I lay awake in bed for hours. Sometimes crying, sometimes wanting to scream, nothing I do gets my mind off of it. No matter what i try to think about or do. Also my dreams lately have been very traumatizing, murders, blood, suicide, everything bad… started around the same time these flashbacks started happening. I have always dealt with my stress, or trauma. It’s never affected me like this… I wake up legitimately fearful from my dreams, or I just can not sleep, when the flashbacks happen NOTHING gets my mind off them… I can’t concentrate… what should I do? Prompt: I am 23 years old, and a female. I have never been in a romantic, sexual relationship with any man (although I have kissed many and really enjoyed it). However the thought of being romantically attached and in a relationship with a women repulses me and makes me sick. I feel extreme anxiety, and it has severely changed my sleeping and eating patterns. I am up all night wondering if I am gay as well as wondering if I will ever have any romantic attachment with a man. As soon as I try and convince myself that I am straight, I panic and feel like I’m lying to myself, and tell myself that I am deep in denial. Every time I go out, I am scared that I will see a girl and fall in love with her and lose all my interest in men, which scares me even more. I came across information about HOCD, and immediately identified with of all the emotional and physical experiences that other people went through, which made me feel a bit more calm. But now I have started to convince myself that what I identified with when I read HOCD was a lie and that deep down I am a closeted gay (even though I know that’s not true). I have spoken to my mother and a few of my friends about how I am feeling which helps me feel less stressed but five minutes later to an hour I convince myself that all I have said was a lie and I am deep in denial, which makes me more depressed.  I don’t know what I am feeling and it scares the hell out of me. I would love to see a therapist but I have too many other expenses in my life so I can’t afford it. Please help me. Prompt: I have been diagnosed with MDD, but am worried I might be Schizophrenic. Eliminating "Fortune-telling" seems unlikely at first glance, as the patient doesn't explicitly predict a negative outcome for themselves or others. However, considering the context of their other symptoms and experiences, I would eliminate this class because it's less likely that the patient has a fixed belief about the inevitability of bad outcomes.

Next, I would eliminate "All-or-Nothing Thinking" because while the patient mentions extreme anhedonia and lethargy, there is no indication that they believe anything short of perfection is unacceptable. They don't seem to have a binary thought pattern where everything is either good or bad.

Eliminating "Labeling" seems unlikely at first glance, as the patient doesn't attach labels to themselves or others. However, considering the context of their other symptoms and experiences, I would eliminate this class because it's less likely that the patient has a fixed self-image.

Considering the remaining classes, I would eliminate "Emotional Reasoning" because while the patient does mention feeling sad when they shouldn't be, this is not presented as a justification for their feelings. Instead, it seems more like an observation about their emotional response.

Next, I would eliminate "Overgeneralization" because while the patient mentions extreme anhedonia and lethargy, there is no indication that they are drawing sweeping negative conclusions from limited instances.

Considering the remaining classes, I would eliminate "Magnification" because while the patient does mention feeling sad when they shouldn't be, this is not presented as an exaggeration of their emotions. Instead, it seems more like an observation about their emotional response.

Finally, I am left with "Mental Filter". This class seems likely because the patient focuses primarily on the negative aspects of their experiences (e.g., extreme anhedonia, lethargy, difficulty getting emotionally attached to people) and doesn't mention any positive aspects or balanced perspectives.

Prompt: From the U.S.: Hello, my newlywed husband and I have had the fairy tale relationship- a kind I have dreamt about. Recently, his grandmother passed away after a lengthy fight against numerous medical conditions. He was extremely close to her. Originally, I believe he was shocked, and just cried into me. However, a week later, he became angry over the simplest things and threatened to leave me if I didn’t do XYZ (clean the house better, etc.). He had never said anything of the kind before. The next day he apologized and life was back to normal for a week. He said he loves me and can’t wait for our life together and is never going anywhere.
Response:
Let's start eliminating classes from the patient question:

1. Labeling: I eliminated this class because there is no indication that the husband has labeled himself or others with negative terms such as "loser" or "perfect". The language used in the anecdote does not suggest any self-labeling or attributing labels to his behavior.

2. Fortune-telling: I eliminated this class because there is no prediction of a specific outcome, especially one that would always result in the worst possible outcome. The husband's behavior after his grandmother passed away was unpredictable and varied from day to day.

3. Mind Reading: I eliminated this class because there is no indication that the husband believes he knows how the patient feels or what she thinks about his behavior. The anecdote focuses on the husband's actions and emotions, not on the patient's thoughts or feelings.

4. Personalization: I eliminated this class because the husband's behavior was not directly caused by the patient's actions or words. His anger and threats were in response to specific situations (e.g., cleaning the house), which are outside of the patient's control.

5. Magnification: I eliminated this class because while the husband did become angry, it was not described as extreme or exaggerated. The anecdote does not suggest that his behavior was disproportionate to the situation.

6. Emotional Reasoning: I eliminated this class because there is no indication that the husband believes his emotions are a reliable indicator of reality. While he may have expressed anger and frustration, the anecdote suggests that these feelings were short-lived and varied from day to day.

7. Overgeneralization: I eliminated this class because the husband's behavior was not described as a sweeping generalization based on limited instances. His change in behavior was specific to certain situations (e.g., cleaning the house), rather than a broad pattern.

8. Mental Filter: I eliminated this class because while the anecdote does focus on the negative aspects of the husband's behavior, it also mentions that life returned to normal and he apologized. The balance between positive and negative emotions is present in the anecdote.

9. All-or-Nothing Thinking: I eliminated this class because there is no indication that the husband believes that anything short of perfect behavior from him would be unacceptable or a failure. The anecdote suggests that his behavior was variable and influenced by specific situations.

10. Should Statements: I eliminated this class because while the husband did make demands (e.g., cleaning the house), these are not framed as "should" statements, which imply a moral obligation rather than a request or expectation.

11. No Distortion: This is the remaining class. The patient's anecdote describes a nuanced and balanced picture of her husband's behavior, with both positive and negative emotions present. While there were instances of anger and frustration, these were followed by apologies and a return to normalcy.

Now I would eliminate "Labeling" because there's no mention of labeling themselves or their boyfriend with negative terms like "loser".

I would also eliminate "Magnification" because while the patient does admit to creating problems out of thin air, they don't seem to be exaggerating the severity of these problems.

Next, I would eliminate "Overgeneralization" because the patient's statement that they will find reasons to get upset is a general tendency, rather than a sweeping conclusion based on limited instances.

Now I would eliminate "Mental Filter" because while the patient does focus on negative aspects of their relationship, they also acknowledge the positive aspects and express love for their boyfriend.

Next, I would eliminate "Emotional Reasoning" because the patient doesn't seem to be using their emotions as a basis for rationalizing their thoughts or behaviors. They're more aware of their tendency to get upset and are commenting on it rather than justifying it emotionally.

Now I'm left with two possibilities: "All-or-Nothing Thinking" and "Magnification". However, the patient's statement seems more aligned with "Magnification" because they acknowledge creating problems out of thin air, but don't seem to be viewing every situation as an all-or-nothing proposition. They also express love and appreciation for their boyfriend, which suggests that they're not catastrophizing or expecting a complete failure.

But upon further consideration, I think the patient's statement is more accurately described by "Should Statements" in the sense that they are aware of their tendency to create problems out of thin air, but still feel like they should be able to avoid doing so. This sense of expectation and self-blame suggests a "should" tone.

However, considering this again, I think the patient's statement is more closely aligned with "Emotional Reasoning". The patient states that they will find reasons to get upset even though they know it's irrational, which implies that their emotions are driving their thoughts rather than justifying them. They seem to be acknowledging that they're not thinking rationally, but still can't help getting upset.

I would eliminate "All-or-Nothing Thinking" and instead conclude that the patient is engaging in "Emotional Reasoning", as this class seems to best capture the idea that their emotions are driving their thoughts rather than justifying them.

Class: Emotional Reasoning

In 2013 I tried to seek help, I think I was suffering PTSD. After wanting me in group therapy I ran and never went back. I also have substance abuse problems, Im irrational and impulsive, and making common decisions is difficult. I shake constantly, always weak but sometimes feel invincible. I may be anemic but nothing confirms it. I sometimes see things that aren’t there but rarely. I dont like people by any means, nor do I have much empathy. To keep my relationships okay sometimes I fake or overly act certain emotions I know I should have. I crave power and glory, to a point it should be a concern, yet sometimes lack motivation? I know I have experienced depression on many,many occasions. There’s things I’d like to do but I know I never could. I’ve been anticipating a major breakdown for about 8 from suppression, hiding, and faking. Ive had a great deal of tragedies, sexual abuse, abandonment, various suicides. I saved a friend once as a teen, I cut myself fairly bad, but I succeeded in taking the box cutter away after he cut his wrists, throat, and tried to stab his stomach. It plays out in my dreams like I remember, when I awake many things I’ve suppressed flood my head. Overall though the things I want to do, the things I find acceptable etc. thats what is scaring me, also that I can’t remember things.. I guess all of it. The thought of seeking actual help, I know what I feel isn’t normal, but I fear what will become of me or my family if I go and completely honest.

Prompt: I didn’t realize I was suffering from depression until many years into it. I finally went to a psychologist and psychiatrist when my life was falling apart. My doctors advised me against it, saying that if I had suffered more than 3 episodes, I should stay on medication indefinitely, but I had never “counted” my episodes. Really, it just felt like I was born with one long and nasty episode. I have been off my meds for a month now and I feel horrible. My anxiety is so bad that my whole body hurts from being so tense and shaky. I’m missing work either because I’m too busy crying or I just don’t want to deal with life. I feel lonely, sad, and hopeless. I feel like I am cursed for life. From what I have read and heard, depression occurs in episodes. But I feel like I am doomed to feel like this forever, having no respite unless I take high doses of medications. Is it possible that I just have a “lifetime long episode”? I only went to see a psychiatrist when I was 22, about a year after I moved out of my parents house. My parents are deniers of mental illness – the have a “pick yourself up by your bootstraps” / “you can’t possibly have depression” attitudes, so I always attributed my poor mental status to a character flaw. But when I reflect on my childhood and adolescence, I don’t ever remember being happy. I think I was always depressed. I cannot possibly live my life feeling this depressed but I don’t want to take medication for the rest of my life either. I haven’t even mentioned that my medications and behavioral therapies have done absolutely nothing to help my OCD. That I have heard can last a lifetime. I don’t think I can live like this. Prompt: I met a my best friend when I was 16 and we started dreaming of doing amazing things. We decided to go to France after highschool (we were 18) and study robotics and then later on founded an NGO about education. All was good except my studies. I never graduated from my associate degree in mechanical engineering and that’s when the lying started. I lied to my family back home in Morocco and I’ve been lying to him. I told everyone that I graduated and that I was enrolled in a Masters of engineering. Trouble came when I had to apply for a renewal to my residence permit in France. I couldn’t provide grade reports so I was refused the stay and had to go back home. That’s when I told my best friend the truth. My mum found out after I got home. The problem now is that there are still people (friends) in my life that I’m still lying to. I’m currently enrolled in an engineering degree in Morocco (after 2 years of only focusing on creating the NGO I mentioned and working with my best friend who didn’t give up on me and slowly got me out of my little depression). How did I let things get to such a bad outcome? I don’t know. I suffer from a serious case of laziness and inconsistency. I know I have the potential to do great things, I still get involved in too much endeavors but I can’t produce results. I still don’t know why. Now, let's look at "Fortune-telling". The patient doesn't seem to be predicting a specific outcome or assuming that things will always go badly. They're more focused on understanding why they got into this situation in the first place.

I'll also eliminate "Mind Reading" as it doesn't appear to be relevant to the anecdote. There's no indication that the patient is assuming others are reacting negatively to them without basis.

Next, I'll examine "Magnification". While the patient does exaggerate their perceived failure ("I never graduated"), this might not necessarily be an example of magnification. They're more focused on understanding why they got into this situation rather than catastrophizing it.

Now, let's look at "Emotional Reasoning". The patient doesn't seem to be using emotions as evidence for their thoughts or assumptions. Instead, they're trying to understand the underlying reasons for their behavior.

Now, let's look at "All-or-Nothing Thinking" again. While the patient does use phrases like "I never graduated", this might be more of an emotional response rather than a thought pattern that's driving their behavior.

Finally, I'm left with two classes: "Emotional Reasoning" and "Magnification". However, upon re-examining the anecdote, I think "Magnification" is a better fit.
